reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Cp response to vulnerable children in Hasakeh, Raqqa governorat

description.narrative:
key interventions and issues to be addressed in those location GBV: - Preventing violence by addressing the causes, contributing factors and risks- Confronting violence and its effects to meet the needs of survivors- Provide psychological “first aid” to survivors of sexual violence- -Prepare media, education and communication training materials to mobilize communities to prevent gender-based violence and refer survivors to Services. CP:- - Activities to uphold children's rights and raise awareness, and support discuss MA:- Raise awareness on risk posed by explosive hazards through direct risk education sessions- Circulate safety messages- Data collection in vulnerable communities- Communication with the community-
The NGO will establish Al-Ihsan: Hassakeh: mobile teams for Al Malikeyyeh( Maabada)And( Ya'robiyah) in Hassakeh .2 - Raqqa: Mobile teams for Raqqa rural and Ein Issa rural(Rashidiyeh,Arida Ojeil) .2- Static facilities in Raqqa cities (AndalusM) .1- Community based CP and awareness activities including GBV.- -Case management and access to specialized response including identification of separated/Unaccompanied children and provision of needed -Identification of GBV risks, Sensitive approach towards GBV survivors, and implementation of Structured awareness sessions for children and for care givers about GBV. -A protective environment is enabled through enhanced awareness and advocacy , to avoid the risks of explosive remnants due to risk education Unclear situation: no schools, no work and unable to support their families The social center will provide a quiet space for IDPs and low-income people from the host community, and will provide a range of social and recreational activities for children, in addition to awareness (CP, GBV, ERW), and the center is a point of contact with the community, knowing their needs and providing the required services within or through Situation management to services Most of the activities available at the center depend on the participation of IDPs. - Al-Ihssan Association has more than 345 employees and its average partner with UNICEF, and the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs working in all areas of Al-Hassakeh, Al-Raqqa and Deir Al-Zor. This attitude made charity able to collect information about the growing needs of the population, Including the impact of cerebral palsy status on the most vulnerable IDPs, IDPs, returnees and the host community. Needs were assessed in Al-Malikiyah, Al-Maabadah and Al-Raqqa in its countryside and Ain Issa and Al-Tabqa through its working groups (there is no work for displaced families and cannot support their families and most families are coming from Ain Issa camp with regard to Al-Raqqa, students have lost schools, and therefore they have lost their educational future, losing the social network Fear, sadness, depression, the inability to adapt to the new situation, the absence of a map of services in areas of displacement, the large number of separated and unaccompanied children in Raqqa) Ihsan is a very active player in the governorates of Hasaka and Raqqa, and he has become well known in the community, among other stakeholders, and United Nations agencies. The project targets children and mothers. Children will be divided into groups of one child's brother and we will reduce stress, depression and fear caused by the crisis. Al-Ihsan is one of the leading NGOs in Al-Hasakah in providing assistance to multiple sectors, including helping to protect the most vulnerable groups. Al-Ihsan NGO targets all different groups of beneficiaries. During 2015 to 2019, Al-Ihsan worked in protection projects in cooperation with UNICEF, and he managed to provide 80,000 beneficiaries of protection in Al-Hasakeh, Al-Raqqa, and Deir Al-Zour through
